definition: Xu Shen (-147) the compiler of the original Han dynasty dictionary Shuowen Jiezi 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
to allow/to permit/to promise/to praise/somewhat/perhaps
surname Xu
careful/cautious
old variant of 慎[shen4]

sentences.english: Such a structure reflects the philosophy of the writer.
sentences.chinese: 这种编纂法也反映了许慎的哲学思想。

sentences.english: The use of the skull echoes Xu Shen’s definition of the fox as a vehicle for ghosts.
sentences.chinese: 利用骷髅，回应了许慎的狐狸定义“鬼之乘物”。

sentences.english: "At this point, Duanshi corrected Xu Shen's argument that" Lun also voice.
sentences.chinese: 在此，段氏纠正了许慎的说法，认为“仑亦声”。

definition: Shuowen Jiezi, the original Han dynasty Chinese character dictionary with 10,516 entries, authored by Xu Shen 許慎|许慎[Xu3 Shen4] in 2nd century
see 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
Commentary on Shuowen Jiezi (1815) by Duan Yucai 段玉裁[Duan4 Yu4 cai2]
Yupian, Chinese dictionary compiled by Gu Yewang 顧野王|顾野王[Gu4 Ye3 wang2] in 6th century AD
Zheng Xuan (127-200), late Han scholar
original meaning/literal sense
History of the Former Han Dynasty, second of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], composed by Ban Gu 班固[Ban1 Gu4] in 82 during Eastern Han (later Han), 100 scrolls

Six Methods of forming Chinese characters, according to Han dictionary Shuowen 說文|说文 - namely, two primary methods: 象形 (pictogram), 指事 (ideogram), two compound methods: 會意|会意 (combined ideogram), 形聲|形声 (ideogram plus phonetic), and two transfer methods: 假借 (loan), 轉注|转注 (transfer)
miscellany of writing from the Western Han (aka Former Han)
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
Ban Gu (32-92), Eastern Han dynasty historian, wrote the Dynastic History of Western Han 漢書|汉书
Luxuriant Dew of the Spring and Autumn Annals, ideological tract by Han dynasty political philosopher Dong Zhongshu 董仲舒[Dong3 Zhong4 shu1]
expert on writing systems
inscription in bronze/bell-cauldron inscription
Guangyun, Chinese rime dictionary 韻書|韵书[yun4 shu1] from 11th century, containing 26,194 single-character entries
Liu Xi (late Han, c. 200 AD), possibly the author of 釋名|释名[Shi4 ming2]
